prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for wearing earbuds and occasionally checking my phone during a church mass that I am forced to go to even though I am an atheist?
My parents have recently had a interest in going to church for the past month or so, so every Sunday, they force me to attend mass with them. I have told them multiple times that I don't believe in what they believe, but they brush it off and force me to come anyways. So this time, I brought earbuds and put on an album to listen to (Stokeley by Ski Mask the Slump God is great; listen to it) because I wanted to listen to my music instead. I would also text my friend every 15 minutes or so. During the entire mass, my mom shot me dirty looks the whole time and later told me on the ride home that I have a horribly negative attitude and that I should enjoy things more (even though I have told them countless times that I don't believe in what they do and dislike attending church.

Am I just being a bitch or are my parents at fault?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The use of earbuds and texting might be their way of coping with the situation. 

But from a social standpoint, even if the author is being forced, their actions during the service could be seen as impolite. Maybe they should find a more discreet way to cope, like sitting in a less prominent place or finding an alternative. However, the parents are the ones forcing the attendance, so they might bear some responsibility here. 

The question is about whether the author is in the wrong. If we consider the parents' role in forcing attendance, maybe the author isn't entirely at fault. But in terms of behavior during the mass, they might be seen as disrespectful. However, since they're being forced to attend against their will, their actions could be a form of protest. 

So, is it AITA? The answer could be B (not in the wrong) because they're being forced to attend and their actions are a way to cope with an uncomfortable situation. However, some might argue they should find a more respectful way to handle it. I think the key here is the coercion by the parents.
